In high volume sports, such as long distance running, overuse injuries can keep an athlete out of play for long periods of time or be season ending . Stress fractures  in this population are serious overuse injuries that typically occur in the foot and lower leg. These measurements are also low cost, have no health risks, and are easy to apply in clinical assessments .
One major problem with biological light microscopy is the motility of living organisms. The more recent advancements of genetically encoded fluorescent proteins and other in vivo labeling techniques have made the collection of adequate levels of fluorescent light even more critical. The specimen can be treated with an anesthetic or paralyzing chemical; or by various physical means, such as viscous media, or fibrous traps, or by methods of mechanical flattening and immobilization.
The human proteome encodes nearly 1000 integral membrane proteins, representing nearly 30% of all proteins in the cell. Understanding how these membrane proteins function is critical to the molecular medicine and biotechnology fields . They all signal via lateral dimerization in the membrane plane.
Successful breast conservation surgery  maximizes local control when obtaining negative margins prior to irradiation. Although it is well established that compromised margins increase the risk of local recurrence,  no universally accepted definition of a close or negative margin exists because trials have varied widely in their margin definitions, inclusion criteria, and local recurrence rates. , Irrespective of the definition used, negative margins remain the standard of care for BCS, and although the number of re excisions doesn’t affect local recurrence initial efforts to achieve margin negativity may help prevent reoperation.
Hematopoietic progenitors, from the bone marrow, migrate into the thymus and undergo a well regulated developmental program to produce T lymphocytes . The Wnt signaling pathway is an evolutionarily conserved pathway that regulates cell proliferation, differentiation, cell survival, migration, and polarity . Deletion of Ctnnb1  results in a developmental blockage at the DN3 to DN4 stage.
Arterial flow mediated dilation  is an indirect measurement of endothelial nitric oxide  release. Impaired FMD represents systemic vascular endothelial dysfunction that is commonly associated with cardiovascular disease ., Additionally, the association of FMD with CVD is evidenced by its ability to predict future CVD events in population based studies., Endothelial dysfunction, defined by impaired FMD, has been reported in patients with atrial fibrillation ., Also, abnormalities in NO signaling have been implicated in atrial ectopy near the pulmonary veins., These findings suggest a potential role for endothelial dysfunction in the development of AF. However, data from population based studies to support this claim are lacking.
Joint attention is an early emerging social communication skill that involves sharing interest regarding an object, person, or event with a social partner . Using shared positive affect during joint attention can be an especially powerful way to inform a communicative partner about the emotional significance of a shared experience . For example, a child may smile at an adult while using a joint attention point to convey his excitement about a toy.
Episodic antiretroviral therapy was suggested as a way of retaining the benefits of combination antiretroviral therapy while minimizing adverse effects of antiretroviral drugs , . However, interruption of antiretroviral therapy results in viral rebound, and plasma HIV RNA levels are closely associated with the risk of perinatal and heterosexual transmission of HIV . Therefore, one of the concerns about episodic antiretroviral therapy is the possibility of increased risk of HIV transmission to sexual and needle sharing partners  .
Functional brain imaging has revealed one set of brain areas that show increases in activity and a separate set of areas that show decreases in activity during performance of a wide range of different types of cognitive tasks. Task positive regions include dorsolateral prefrontal, precentral, and inferior parietal cortices . This interpretation of the data is nicely expressed by Fox, et al .
Deregulation of intrinsic tumor protective mechanisms can convert normal epithelia into malignant carcinoma, and lies at the heart of the majority of human cancers. p53 is a pivotal regulator that protects from such events. However, with regards to p63, a more complicated picture has emerged.
A central challenge in synthetic biology is to construct reliable and useful biological systems in a predictable manner . A typical design process entails multiple rounds of gene circuit modeling, construction, and optimization. As has been noted, however, a circuit is functional only in the context of its host and its activation may invoke unintended interactions with the host ,,.
Human induced pluripotent stem cells  offer a virtually unlimited source of cardiac myocytes  for disease modeling, drug testing and cardiac regeneration therapies, but current cardiac directed differentiation techniques  lead to heterogeneous populations containing cardiac cells with ventricular, atrial and pacemaker phenotypes as well as other cell lineages and residual undifferentiated cells . Ventricular, atrial and pacemaker myocytes have distinct contractile and electrophysiological properties , and development of methodologies to generate pure populations of these cardiac cell types would represent a major advance towards the use of hiPSC derived CMs  in clinical research and regenerative medicine . Furthermore, the usefullness of hiPSC CMs in patient specific drug testing and cardiac regeneration would be strengthened if homogenous cell populations were available .
Down syndrome  arises from the genetic consequences of trisomy 21 and is a disorder of gene dosage. Cytogenetic mapping of rare patients with partial duplications of chromosome 21q and DS associated phenotypes had led to the concept of a Down syndrome critical region  at 21q22.2, minimal duplication of which is sufficient to lead to mental retardation and the DS facial gestalt . Indeed, specific genes  within the DSCR in mouse models causing NFAT dysregulation lead to DS like heart defects .
The symptoms of common mental disorders, can lead to clinically significant impairment or distress , which can be alleviated by a variety of treatments, including, possibly, psychotherapy . Several controlled studies , meta analyses , and guidelines , have indicated the efficacy of psychotherapy for different mental health problems, both when used alone , or in combination with psychotropic medications . There remains, however, debate on methodological issues regarding assessment of psychotherapy efficacy and effectiveness  .
Patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma , which includes cancers of the oral cavity, pharynx, and larynx, have one of the highest rates of depression,  and psychological distress, relative to other cancer patient populations. Several studies have reported that various measures of psychosocial functioning are associated with biological processes, such as angiogenesis,  that may be relevant to cancer progression and outcomes. Angiogenesis has long been recognized to promote tumor growth and metastases and can be stimulated by various proteins including vascular endothelial growth factor .
Evidence for the familial transmission of alcoholism is well established in the empirical literature. Both twin and adoption studies support the heritability of alcoholism for both men and women . This conceptual shift has resulted in more research on the mechanisms through which familial vulnerability operates and includes prospective studies of children in families with an alcoholic parent.
Eukaryotic genomes are pervasively transcribed. RNA polymerase II  is responsible for generating both mRNAs and lncRNAs. As with mRNAs, many lncRNAs are processed , however, in contrast to protein coding mRNAs, lncRNAs are predominantly nuclear and many are rapidly degraded by the exosome, the major cellular 3′→5′ RNA degradation machinery.
In the United States, 28% of adults infected with HIV are parents . Among families affected by parental HIV, research consistently has shown the significant effects of maternal HIV status and distress on adolescent outcomes . To understand the effect of parental HIV on adolescent mental health and behavioral outcomes fully, research must delineate the mediating family processes through which maternal HIV impacts children.
Histidine  tag affinity purification is a method of choice for the purification of a large number of recombinant proteins expressed in various overexpression systems. Information is lacking about quantitative evaluation of this procedure . TTP, a hyperphosphorylated mRNA binding and destabilizing protein , regulates inflammatory responses at the post transcriptional level .
Dental composites of polymer resins and glass filler particles have an esthetically pleasing appearance and adhere well to dental enamel and dentin . The resin is usually composed of methacrylate polymers such as bisphenol A diglycidyl methacrylate  and tetraethyleneglycol dimethacrylate. Both physical and chemical processes affect the degradation of dental composites in the oral cavity .
Infiltrating lobular carcinoma  differs both morphologically and clinically from the more common infiltrating ductal carcinoma  in breast cancer. ILC is more likely to be bilateral, multicentric, and diploid than IDC. Also, ILC tumors have a pattern of metastasis to bone, gastrointestinal tract, and ovary that is different from that of IDC .
The lymphatic system plays an essential role in fluid homeostasis, fat absorption and immune surveillance. The Prox1+ endothelial cells form primary lymph sacs, and from these structures lymphatic vessels subsequently sprout in a process known as lymphangiogenesis . The most common treatments are sclerotherapy for macrocystic  LMs and surgical resection for microcystic  LMs.
Uterine leiomyomata are tumors enriched in extracellular matrix  proteins that contribute to the symptomatic bulk of these tumors. Leiomyomas represent an excellent model for the study of disease processes involving disrupted ECM . Versican is a versatile ECM proteoglycan that contributes to the structural properties of the matrix through its ability to bind hyaluronan and the glycosaminoglycan  chondroitin sulfate, thereby influencing cell growth, migration, and differentiation.
HIV/AIDS continues to be a serious threat to the wellbeing of young people in the United States and around the world . Approximately 5% of people living with HIV in the United States are between the ages of 13 and 24; they represent 46,500 persons . Youth constitute a vulnerable group because they are passing through a period of sexual development in which curiosity and lack of accurate information are commonly coupled with sexual initiation and experimentation  .
Desmosomes are specialized intercellular adhesive junctions found in simple and stratified epithelium, and are vital for the integrity and stability of these tissues . Although desmosomes are traditionally considered as epithelial junctions, they are also found in the intercalated discs of cardiomyocytes in specialized hybrid structures of desmosomes and adherens junctions, called area composita. The desmosomal complex of proteins includes the armadillo repeat containing proteins plakoglobin  and plakophilins; the desmosomal cadherins, desmocollins 13 and, desmogleins  14; and the plakins, desmoplakin , envoplakin, periplakin, plectin, bullous pemphigoid antigen 1, and microtubule actin cross linking factor.
Relapse occurs in 15 to 20% of pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia  and 50% of adult ALL patients. Compared to de novo leukemia, relapsed leukemia is chemoresistant and long term survival is poor, however the genetic basis for this is not well understood. Studies of matched diagnosis and relapse ALL samples by SNP arrays demonstrated that 92% of relapsed ALL had DNA copy number variant  changes from diagnosis.
Rheumatoid arthritis  is a chronic inflammatory and destructive arthropathy of unknown etiology. In RA, the synovial lining increases from 1 to 2 cell layers to as much as 10 layers thick and is composed of macrophages and fibroblasts. Since there is a paucity of apoptotic cells in RA joint, one potential mechanism responsible for the hyperplasia in synovial lining may be attributed to decreased death of fibroblasts and macrophages.
Accelerated hypofractionated partial breast irradiation  condenses the standard 6 weeks of radiation treatment into 5 days, offering logistical and quality of life benefits . Results from studies evaluating various interstitial brachytherapy systems have proven to yield local failure rates as low as 05.7% at up to 65 months, as well as good to excellent cosmetic results in 67  97% of patients . Early and late normal tissue complications are thought to be comparable to other modes of APBI .
Langerhans cells  are dendritic cells that reside in the epidermis. Recently, however, data was presented that challenged this paradigm. Based on our earlier work showing that CGRP inhibits LC Ag presentation in several models including presentation to a Th1 clone , we hypothesized that CGRP may act by biasing LC towards inducing Th2 type immunity .
Alcohol consumption has been established as a major risk factor for esophageal cancer , which remains one of the most common and fatal malignancies worldwide  . Although the biological mechanisms underlying alcohol induced carcinogenesis have not been fully understood, the metabolism of ethanol has been suggested to play an important role in the development of EC  . In alcohol metabolism, alcohol dehydrogenases  oxidize alcohol to acetaldehyde, which was classified as a Group I human carcinogen by the International Agency of Research on Cancer  .
Genital Chlamydia trachomatis infection in humans leads to pathological sequelae in the upper genital tract  including pelvic inflammatory disease, ectopic pregnancy and infertility . The incidence of genital chlamydial infection has continued to increase over the last decade despite the availability of efficacious antimicrobial therapy . A licensed preventive vaccine is thought to be the solution to this problem, but has yet to be developed .
The elevation of nitric oxide  in skin cells after ultraviolet light B  irradiation plays an important role in regulation of apoptosis . UVB also induces the production of superoxide  , which could rapidly react with NO• to form peroxynitrite  . Our recent study indicated that UVB induced imbalance of NO•/ONOO− promotes apoptotic cell death .
Glyceraldehyde 3 phosphate dehydrogenase, spermatogenic , the sperm specific isoform of human GAPDH , is under active study as a male contraceptive target . In contrast to the somatic form of GAPDH, the sperm specific GAPDHS possesses a unique proline rich extension at the amino terminus which varies between species ), and may mediate binding to the fibrous sheath in the sperm flagellum  . We have had similar difficulties obtaining high yields of soluble protein when expressing recombinant mouse or human GAPDHS in E. coli.
TGFβ inducible early gene 1 , also referred to as KLF10, was originally cloned from human osteoblasts  as a primary response gene following TGFβ treatment . Over expression of TIEG in pancreatic carcinoma and hepatocarcinoma cells also inhibited cell proliferation and induced apoptosis similar to that of TGFβ . TIEG also plays an important role in mediating the TGFβ Smad signaling pathway.
The wide range in contractile, biochemical and morphological properties among muscle fibers is a common feature of skeletal muscle in virtually all animal species . It is well documented that the innervating motoneurons play a key role in the maintenance and plasticity of the differentiated muscle phenotype including fiber size, metabolic profile and contractile properties . Skeletal muscle gene expression is controlled by a complex group of regulators that derive from one of two major families of transcription factors.
The Transforming Growth Factor β  superfamily comprises a large number of cytokines that regulate tissue homeostasis and development through the regulation of fundamental processes such as cell proliferation, differentiation, motility and programmed cell death. TGF β has been shown to not only play a central role in development and normal organ function, but also to affect many pathological processes such as cirrhosis, nephrosclerosis, and tumorigenesis ) . Additional evidence for a tumor suppressor role for the TGF _ signaling pathway is derived from studies of mouse models of cancer.
Non small cell lung cancer  is the leading cause of cancer death in the United States and worldwide . Five year survival rate of NSCLC patients is only 13%. The development of highly reliable and noninvasive diagnostic tools would facilitate the early detection of lung cancer, and is thus clinically important .
During development of the central nervous system , differentiation of the myelinating cells, oligodendrocytes, and the process of active myelination itself are regulated by complex interactions of the oligodendrocytes’ cell surfaces with their extracellular environments . These interactions are to a large extent mediated by the integrin class of extracellular matrix  receptors . FAK, also known as protein tyrosine kinase 2 , is an ubiquitously expressed non receptor protein tyrosine kinase that can be activated by a number of extracellular signals .
Targeting interventions to characteristics of specific groups of patients has been supported in research studies and frequently discussed as desirable. While a positive finding of efficacy or effectiveness of an intervention provides evidence base for clinical practice, a negative finding could result from differing effects of the intervention on subgroups of the population. The examination of moderating effects of patient characteristics on intervention efficacy is fraught with difficulty.
In the United States, employees are legally entitled to a safe and healthy workplace. Surveillance systems capture these data and are key for designing effective interventions to improve worker safety and health . Severe weather has always threatened human health.
Chronic kidney disease, particularly end stage renal disease  treated with hemodialysis, is a powerful, independent risk factor for coronary artery disease  . In addition, traditional risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes and hyperlipidemia are common coexisting conditions. This highly atherogenic milieu in patients with ESRD results in a CAD associated mortality 1020 times greater than the normal population  .
The development of a non invasive imaging methodology that is both sensitive and specific to white matter  pathologies would be very valuable for the diagnosis, characterization and follow up of different WM associated disorders of the central nervous system . Diffusion tensor MRI  has been widely used to study and follow WM disorders . In most diffusion studies of neuronal tissues to date, the data have been analyzed using the well known StejskalTanner equation , which assumes the existence of a single unrestricted diffusing component and therefore, in biological tissues, provides a population averaged apparent diffusion coefficient.
Depressive symptoms are common in elderly hospitalized patients, with significant symptom levels occurring in 10 to 44% of patients. The presence of depressive symptoms during hospitalization is associated with adverse outcomes, a finding initially noted among select patient groups such as those with acute myocardial infarction. , It is now recognized that among elderly patients hospitalized with a range of medical diagnoses, those with depressive symptoms are at increased risk of poor post hospitalization outcomes including worse physical and mental health, functional decline and increased mortality.
Griscelli syndrome  is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the MYO5A , RAB27A , or MLPH  genes . All GS patients present with hypomelanosis of the skin due to abnormal melanosomal trafficking in melanocytes and silvery gray hair due to the presence of large clumps of pigment in hair shafts. HLH manifests as episodes of uncontrolled activation of T lymphocytes and macrophages and, without a bone marrow transplant, is typically fatal in early childhood for patients with GS2 .
Steroid hormone receptors bind hormones such as estrogen, glucocorticoid or progesterone within the cell and then regulate transcription of steroid responsive genes. Hence, the RNA was entitled “steroid receptor RNA activator”, or “SRA”. It was subsequently proposed that SRA asserts similar regulatory effects on transcription in additional biological contexts, such as myogenesis  and adipogenesis , reviewed recently in  .
Over the past decade, transcatheter cardiac ablation  procedures for treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias have become routine in hospitals around the world. Reported rates of arrhythmia recurrence post TCA are typically around 20%, and studies have attributed arrhythmia recurrence to incomplete lesions or electrical conduction through unablated gaps in isolation lines. Electroanatomical mapping  systems are the current clinical standard for guiding RFA lesion placement.
Prostate development begins prenatally when fetal androgens bind to androgen receptors in UGS mesenchyme to stimulate prostatic ductal progenitors, or buds in UGS epithelium. Buds are specified along three asymmetric axes: dorsoventral, craniocaudal, and mediolateral. The second stage of bud formation is the initiation stage, when buds first project from the UGS epithelial surface.
The Lsm proteins were identified in Saccharomyces cerevisiae by their sequence similarity to the canonical Sm proteins . As these RNAs are all nuclear and, with the exception of the U6 snRNA, their associations with the Lsm proteins are highly transient, this suggests that at least some of the Lsm proteins enter the nucleus separately from their target RNAs . Production of recombinant human LSm proteins in bacteria, followed by their injection into HeLa cells, showed that pre assembled LSm2 8 complex localized to the nucleus, whereas LSm8 injected by itself accumulated in the cytoplasm .
Fulminant hepatic failure is a life threatening condition that is treated by transplantation of the liver when a donor organ can be found. Therefore, treatment of hepatic failure could be dramatically improved by development of methods for temporary hepatic support . Thus, the use of a liver assist devices  has greater theoretic potential as a minimally intrusive therapy, as incorporated hepatocytes might provide additional metabolic capacity and physiologically active molecules important for recovery of native hepatic function  .
Adolescent involvement in gangs is a serious public health problem, with an estimated 788 000 youths involved in 27 000 gangs in the United States in 2007 . Gang membership is typically characterized by engagement in some form of criminal activity, such as fighting with other gangs, stealing cars or other goods, selling illegal drugs, or engaging in property damage . Accordingly, gang members report higher rates of violent offending, nonviolent delinquency, and victimization than their peers .
Persistent oxidative damage to cellular DNA associated with chronic inflammation developed in response to microbial and viral infections, tobacco smoke, and other environmental insults, is genotoxic and has been implicated in the etiology of many human cancers . The most common DNA lesion detected in vivo is 8 oxo 7,8 dihydroguanine , a well known biomarker of oxidative stress . This lesion is mutagenic because it mispairs with A during replication by DNA polymerases that lead to a predominant G → T transversion mutation , the second most common somatic mutation in human carcinomas .
Dendritic Cells  are critical antigen presenting cells  characterized by their efficient conversion of internalized antigens into peptide MHC complexes  required to orchestrate T cell responses . Critical DC functions such as antigen presentation, expression of co stimulatory molecules and migration are tightly controlled by a maturation process, where stimuli such as Toll like receptor  ligands or inflammatory cytokines convert immature DCs into mature DCs specialized for T cell stimulation  . Manipulation of DC maturation shows high therapeutic potential, especially in vaccination regimes where antigen delivery to DCs is coordinated with a maturation stimulus to optimize T cell stimulation .
Allergic airway inflammation is a complex disease that involves generation, mobilization, trafficking and recruitment of multiple inflammatory cells, including T helper type 2  cells, eosinophils, neutrophils and natural killer  cells to the airways . Amongst these, eosinophils play a prominent pro inflammatory role in airway allergic inflammation , contributing to several of the clinical features of allergic asthma . Clinical studies as well as murine models of allergic airway inflammation have shown up regulation of bone marrow  eosinophils and their progenitors .
The correct and consistent use of condoms during sexual activity can effectively reduce the transmission of HIV,, so condom use is regularly measured as a proxy for HIV risk. Because no gold standard exists for measuring condom use, researchers have developed a myriad of condom related questions, answered through self report, to assess this behavior. Responses can be influenced by social desirability bias, participation bias, and memory error.
Approximately 2.4 million people in India  are infected with HIV; the vast majority of these  are infected via heterosexual sex . Recent national declines in the epidemic have been attributed to targeted intervention campaigns directed at FSWs and their male clients . Interventions focused on HIV prevention among wives at risk for contracting HIV from their husbands are needed in India, particularly in high epidemic areas of the country, such as Mumbai  .
Traumatic brain injury  is a major cause of acquired disability in children , which results in physical impairments and difficulty with cognition, mood, behavior, social development, and school performance . Many children also experience changes in their sleep patterns after TBI that could contribute to irritability, disrupted sleep, and daytime somnolence . Parents report increased daytime somnolence and prolonged nocturnal sleep in grade school children for months to years after severe TBI compared with mild TBI and controls .
Poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas of conventional type  and oncocytic  type  are biologically situated between well differentiated papillary  and follicular  thyroid carcinomas on the one hand and anaplastic thyroid carcinomas  on the other. A consensus meeting was held in 2007 and a diagnostic algorithm was developed by different experts in thyroid pathology throughout the world . PDs can be admixed with well differentiated thyroid tumors like PTCs or FTCs but even a small PD component determines the patient outcome .
TAR DNA binding protein of 43 kDa  is the major component of protein aggregates in patients with sporadic and most familial ALS and in a subclass of patients with frontotemporal lobar degeneration  characterized by ubiquitin positive inclusions . Moreover, mutations in the gene encoding TDP43 are associated with familial ALS and FTLD with motor neuron disease, strengthening the conclusion that this protein plays a central role in disease pathogenesis  . TDP 43 is a widely expressed nuclear protein that binds DNA and RNA, inhibits retroviral replication, and participates in RNA splicing and nuclear body formation .
Neurosteroids are endogenous steroid molecules in the brain that can allosterically potentiate or inhibit GABAA receptor function . Enhancing neurosteroids, such as 5α, 3α THDOC, play a role in depression, seizure susceptibility, ethanol action, and many other nervous system functions . Further investigation into the structural basis of neurosteroid potentiation and inhibition of GABAA receptors will be important to better understand the physiological basis of neurosteroid effects on behavior, and to exploit their therapeutic potential .
Neural proliferation has been recorded in adults animals of all vertebrate taxa and, with few exceptions, occurs in the cell layer surrounding the lateral ventricles, the ventricular zone  . In mammals these cells migrate largely to the hippocampus and olfactory bulb areas , whereas in songbirds many neurons migrate to nuclei of the efferent motor pathway for learned vocalization  . Steroids are among the factors affecting neural proliferation.
Influenza A viruses cause a highly contagious respiratory disease that results in approximately 36,000 deaths annually in the United States . The annual  viruses currently circulating in humans are comprised of two subtypes with antigenically distinct surface hemagglutinin  and neuraminidase  surface proteins, H1N1 and H3N2. The most severe pandemic occurred in 1918, which was caused by a H1N1 virus.
Dopaminergic amacrine  cells are retinal interneurons that modulate a variety of key visual processes, most notably, those associated with light adaptation and the transition from scotopic to photopic visual function . In the mouse retina, the DA cells are all positioned within the inner nuclear layer , extending their dendritic and axonal processes primarily within the outermost stratum of the inner plexiform layer , in S1 . The DA cells are one of the sparsest cell types within the retina, amounting to less than one hundredth of 1% of all retinal neurons.
Methylphenidate is one of the most frequently prescribed medications for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder . Its prescription usage has been rising along with increasing public awareness of the morbidity and disability associated with this disorder, and the critical importance of successful diagnosis and treatment . Since these safety concerns cannot be adequately studied in humans, animal models have been employed to examine the mechanisms of action of methylphenidate and its addictive potential .
Worldwide, there are over 350 million individuals chronically infected with the human hepatitis B virus ; approximately 25% of chronically HBV infected individuals will develop hepatocellular carcinoma  . HBx activities have frequently been studied in transformed or immortalized cell lines, sometimes not of liver origin, and the precise effect of HBx on cellular signal transduction pathways and on HBV replication has varied in different experimental systems ). Consequently, the role of HBx during HBV replication in normal hepatocytes, and which HBx activities might contribute to the development of HCC, remains incompletely understood.
The behavioral economic approach to the study of cross temporal decision making conceptualizes addiction as a disorder of restricted time horizon , where future consequences falling beyond the horizon  are not adequately integrated into the valuation of current behavioral alternatives. However, addiction is also characterized by memory deficits , insensitivity to risk , and social cognitive dysfunction beyond generalized addiction related social withdrawal . Insights from basic research suggest that these addiction related deficits may simply be different manifestations of a common underlying process .
In order for a tumor to grow beyond approximately 1 2 mm3, it must recruit and form new vasculature as it can no longer rely on the passive diffusion of nutrients . During this process of angiogenesis several growth factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor , are released from both tumor and endothelial cells, and new vessels develop in response to these . For example, the advent of contrast enhanced ultrasound  using microbubbles targeted to specific receptors permits the study of angiogenesis at a molecular level .
Many diseases are characterized by undesired peripheral neural activity. For example, spasticity , chorea, tics and intractable hiccups are all associated with pathological motor activity. These conditions are typically treated pharmacologically, but they may ultimately require surgical, chemical or radiation procedures which result in destruction of the nerve in treatment resistant cases  .
Dysphagia is a serious yet common problem in older adults, especially for those in hospital settings and in sub acute care facilities  . Patients with stroke or hip fracture, the most common reasons for sub acute care admission , are at especially high dysphagia risk. Forty to seventy percent of older adults with acute stroke experience dysphagia .
Microarrays have shown increasing potential as a component of high throughput analytical devices for the rapid detection of biomolecules for a variety of applications such as drug screening. Microarrays of proteins, DNA, carbohydrates, and lipid bilayers have been prepared . Protein microarrays have applications in proteomics and protein functional studies , DNA chips are used in gene expression studies and rapid DNA sequencing , and carbohydrate microarrays can be used in glycomics studies and pathogen identification .
Plasticity in transcription regulation can be achieved by dynamic regulation of histone modifications, particularly on the amino terminal histone tails . Among the lysines that can be acetylated, acetylated H4 K16 is known to play a pivotal role in determining the potential of coding DNA for expression. In vitro biochemical studies revealed that MOF protein alone does not acetylate nucleosomal H4 .
Historically, all diagnostic testing was performed at the patient’s bedside. While the past century has seen the migration of diagnostic testing to the central laboratory for a variety of reasons, over the past couple of decades, however, some diagnostic tests have begun to shift back to the bedside, paving way for the re birth of point of care testing . However, with advances in technology, POCT has now been extended to infectious diseases, cardiac markers, and drugs of abuse.
Aicardi syndrome is a rare neurodevelopmental disorder affecting females and, very rarely, males with a 47,XXY karyotype . The diagnosis of Aicardi syndrome in boys with a 46,XY karyotype has been reported but not confirmed subsequently . Aicardi syndrome is sporadic except for one reported pair of affected sisters  and a pair of affected monozygotic twins .
The production of superoxide from macrophages is a noted antibacterial function of innate immunity. In cell culture, bacterial endotoxins rapidly stimulate superoxide production through assembly and activation of NADPH oxidase, functionally known as the respiratory burst. Exactly how endotoxin activates macrophages to generate superoxide is still largely unknown.
Cleft palate is one of the most commonly observed congenital malformations in humans, occurring in up to 1 in 500 live births. The function of the palate is to separate the oral cavity and nasal cavity to allow respiration, deglutition and phonation to occur. Craniofacial development is a highly regulated process involving the growth and fusion of the maxillary, mandibular and nasal processes.
Anger is related to both acute  and chronic pain intensity . proposed a “symptom specificity” model of chronic pain based on principles of individual response stereotypy . That is, they may reveal strong contraction of low back muscles ) during stress while not necessarily showing such tension increases in muscle groups distant from the pain site.
The active metabolite of vitamin D, 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D 2D3), regulates transcription through its binding to the vitamin D receptor  for subsequent regulation of proliferation and differentiation in a number of cells, including keratinocytes . The VDR binds selectively to genomic sites, termed VDR response elements, and activate transcription . We have previously purified and identified the protein complex of vitamin D receptor interacting proteins  from primary keratinocytes, as well as in the squamous carcinoma cell line SCC12B2  as VDR coactivators.
Butterflies and moths  have a large number of short holocentric chromosomes  with substantial variation in chromosome number  . However, the most common chromosome numbers are n=29 31, , and the distribution is markedly skewed with only a few species having n>31. In spite of much variation in the number of chromosomes, the amount of DNA is approximately the same in different species, suggesting that species with fewer chromosomes have, on average, longer chromosomes.
Natural Killer  cells are a critical component of the immune system where they play a role in viral responses and tumor control. Human NK cells develop from CD34+ hematopoietic stem cells  and must traverse through a number of developmental stages prior to acquisition of CD56 expression and functional competence . NK cell commitment is marked by CD56 expression that can be divided further into two populations of NK cells based on CD56 intensity, with the CD56bright NK cells preceding, and giving rise to the CD56dim NK cells .
Neuroimaging methods play an important role in the process of extending our understanding of brain structure and function. Despite the large number of neuroimaging studies conducted to delineate brain activations related to a wide range of cognitive functions, the fundamental issue of how the brain regions communicate to each other still remains open . Much recent work has focused on measuring and interpreting the spontaneous signal fluctuations typically seen during rest .
Alzheimer's disease , the most common cause of dementia in the elderly, is characterized pathologically by the deposition of β amyloid  plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the hippocampus and cerebral cortex. Because only symptomatic treatments are now available, safe and effective mechanism based therapies are needed for this devastating neurodegenerative disease of later life. The latter is a complex consisting of four distinct membrane proteins, namely presenilin , nicastrin, anterior pharynx defective1 , and presenilin enhancer 2  .
2 deoxy D glucose  is a glucose analogue which, when administered in vivo, can be taken up by cells through glucose transporters. Once intracellular, it undergoes phosphorylation catalyzed by hexokinase but, unlike glucose itself, does not undergo further metabolism but is trapped and accumulates within cells . 2DG has previously been used ex vivo to evaluate cellular function and metabolic activity, and non invasive methods of measurement of 2DG or similar molecules would be valuable for studies of glucose uptake in a variety of applications including assessments of tumors and other pathologies .
The preponderance of research addressing violence against women in the United States focuses on intimate partner violence, meaning physical or sexual violence perpetrated by male partners . In particular, research has shown that women who use illicit drugs are vulnerable to many different types of assailants, including intimate partners, strangers, acquaintances, sex trade clients, police, and drug dealers . Some studies suggest that among women who use drugs, partner assault is not the most common form of violence  .
Asbestos fibers are a naturally occurring hydrated silicate mineral used for commercial applications. Asbestos has two primary classes: serpentine and amphibole. Three examples of amphibole fibers are crocidolite, tremolite, and amosite .
The metabolic syndrome , a highly prevalent condition in the elderly, is associated with potentially reversible risk factors and with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular morbidity and mortality. MetS is also associated with inflammation and hormonal dysfunction,, which in turn are involved in the pathogenesis of anemia . Low hemoglobin levels are common in older subjects, and herald several adverse outcomes like mortality, disability and hospitalization.
Adaptive behavior requires the ability to maintain stable cognitive representations while remaining sensitive to novel information in order to modify behavior based on changing task contexts . Developmental studies have utilized similar tasks to assess cognitive stability and flexibility among children and adolescents ranging from ages 2 to 17 . In addition, there is a second body of research that construes early cognitive control as a dynamic balance between reactivity and regulation, based on relatively stable behaviors that reflect both affective responses to novel stimuli and developing regulatory systems that modulate those affective responses .
Floods have occurred in the recent past, including those during the monsoons of 1998, 2004, and 2007. In addition to flood related epidemics, Bangladesh faces seasonal diarrheal peaks resulting from an increased incidence of waterborne diseases, which are a cause of significant morbidity. , Clinical features of diarrheal diseases seen at health facilities tend to be more severe during floods.
Initially described by Dor in 1989 , endoventricular patch plasty  is used to reduce left ventricular  volume after myocardial infarction  and subsequent LV remodeling. Briefly, the infarct is incised and a purse string suture  used to reduce the circumference of the aneurysm “neck.” The Dor procedure can be performed safely. , However, the NIH sponsored Surgical Treatment for Ischemic Heart failure  trial recently found no difference in composite outcome between coronary bypass  and CABG plus Dor procedure.
Brain development depends on a sequence of cellular and molecular events underlying the process of neuronal generation. Through this sequence, neuronal identity is restricted and defined. Broad distinctions between classes of neurons are largely accomplished through spatially distinct localization of neural progenitor pools.
According to the U.S. National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute's  Asthma Guidelines, the goal of asthma treatment is to improve the quality of life  of people who have asthma, while working toward controlling symptoms, reducing the risk of exacerbations, and preventing asthma related death  . Most notably, past efforts to measure asthma QoL have resulted in tools that can confound QoL with symptoms , functional impairment , and control . The primary objective of the present work responds to this recommendation by developing new freely available instrumentation for measuring the impact of asthma on QoL that avoids confounding QoL with asthma symptomatology and functional impairment, and includes many domains of life important to people with asthma .
The development of new treatments for a disease requires knowledge of the molecular target of those treatments. The social amoeba, Dictyostelium discoideum, is a simple biomedical model commonly used to study developmental and cellular biology. This approach has provided new insights into how current therapeutic agents regulate cellular function , for example, in identifying common signalling pathways targeted by lithium and valproic acid in the treatment of bipolar disorder, and is increasingly being used to identify cellular mechanisms controlling drug targets using growth and development  or cell movement  as phenotypic readouts .
Birds, unlike mammals, have the ability to regenerate hair cells  following damage to the peripheral auditory organ, the basilar papilla   and  for reviews). Aminoglycoside antibiotics cause damage to both short and tall HCs over a region of the papilla extending from the base for a distance that depends on the dose administered and the duration of administration. Recovery of neural and behavioral thresholds after aminoglycoside treatment is correlated with HC regeneration.
Over the past decade, studies of animal models have transformed our understanding of cardiac embryology. In particular, the use of genetic cell lineage analysis, along with the ability to assess large numbers of specimens, has permitted the accurate tracking of distinct cellular contributions within the developing mouse heart. These findings have provided a framework for understanding cardiac development in man, where comparable studies are hampered by limited availability of specimens, and the impossibility of following cell lineage.
Diabetes is a metabolic disease that involves the death or dysfunction of the insulin secreting β cells of the pancreas. Although diabetes can be managed with insulin and other drugs, physiological glucose homeostasis is difficult to achieve by these means, and hyperglycemia is largely responsible for the co morbidities associated with diabetes. NeuroD is a basic helix loop helix  transcription factor that is crucial for development of the pancreas .
Ubiquitination is the process of tagging a target protein with ubiquitin  or a polyubiquitin chain as part of post translational modifications leading to regulatory roles such as protein degradation in the proteosome . The process of ubiquitination is mediated by a cascade of three enzymes known as the ubiquitin activating enzyme , ubiquitin conjugating enzyme  and ubiquitin ligase . Until recently, it was generally accepted that there is only a single subtype of human E1 .
Thyroid hormones  are essential for the normal growth and development of the fetus with even minor perturbations in maternal thyroid status during early pregnancy being associated with neurodevelopmental abnormalities in children in later life . Since effects of maternal thyroid status impact on outcome at a time before development of the thyroid in the fetus, it is clear that supply of maternal THs across the placenta is critical to normal fetal development during pregnancy. Babies born with intrauterine growth restriction  are major contributors to perinatal and neonatal mortality and up to 10% display neurodevelopmental delay .
Iron plays an important role in central nervous system  myelination and inflammation. Macrophages also engulf extravasated red blood cells thereby removing potentially toxic iron containing heme . Through cytokine release, activated macrophages can alter levels of iron and the iron storage protein ferritin .
Assessment of human cancer risk from environmental carcinogen exposures remains a challenging and inexact prospect. According to the March 29, 2005 Guidelines for Carcinogen Risk Assessment , cancer risk is estimated using a human case specific dose response model, if such a model is available . The uncertainties introduced by these extrapolations remains a point of major concern.
Bladder cancer is the sixth most common cancer in the United States, with an estimated 72,570 new cases and 15,210 deaths in 2013 . At presentation, bladder cancer is classified into non muscle invasive , muscle invasive , or metastatic disease. Low grade NMIBC  has a high rate of recurrence but a low rate of progression to MIBC, while high grade NMIBC  has a high rate of recurrence and progression to MIBC .
All trans retinoic acid  is the biologically active derivative of vitamin A. atRA has been considered a potentially promising chemotherapeutic agent, due to its pro apoptotic and growth suppressing activity. The growth of a variety of solid tumors and tumor derived cell lines, including breast, ovarian and colon, has been shown to be inhibited by atRA  . This results from arrest of the cell cycle during the G1 phase .
Dietary restriction  extends lifespan and slows aging across a variety of taxa and also causes myriad other physiological changes . To ascertain which of these processes affected by DR might be causally responsible for DR’s benefits, we have utilized genetic variation underlying a variety of physiological traits in the ILSXISS  series of recombinant inbred  strains of mice . These strains of mice are now available from the Jackson Laboratory .
G protein coupled receptors  comprise a large family of integral membrane proteins that mediate signal transduction across the cell membrane. built models of 26 GPCRs by distance geometry calculations based on interhelical hydrogen bonds. , Reliable homology models are less confidently obtained as the sequence and structure similarity between the template and target decrease.
Recent epidemiological studies have demonstrated a correlation between exposure to fine particulate matter and an increased incidence of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality . Unfortunately the mechanisms behind this correlation remain largely unknown. Iron has two major oxidation states under environmentally relevant conditions: Fe and Fe.
Parkinson’s disease  is a common neurodegenerative disorder characterized clinically by tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability, and pathologically by selective loss of dopaminergic  neurons in affected brain regions. Mutations in leucine rich repeat kinase 2  represent the most frequent cause of autosomal dominant and idiopathic PD identified to date . LRRK2 is a large multi domain protein with both a GTPase and a kinase domain within the same molecule .
Sorbitol is a sugar substitute often used in diet foods  and sugar free chewing gums. It also occurs naturally in many stone fruits and berries from trees of the genus Sorbus. Sorbitol can be used as a non stimulant laxative as either an oral suspension or suppository.
Angiosarcoma  is a rare, usually high grade malignant vascular endothelial tumor comprising less than 1% of all sarcomas. It most commonly involves skin and less commonly deep soft tissue, breast parenchyma, liver, spleen, and bone. Histologically angiosarcomas vary from spindled to epithelioid morphology.
The caries process is potentially preventable and curable. Therefore, one cannot overstate the importance of detecting the decay in the early stage of development at which point non invasive preventive measures can be taken to halt further decay. Light scattering in sound dental enamel decreases markedly in the near infrared  region and studies have shown that enamel has the highest transparency near 1310nm .
Hsp70s are universally conserved and essential protein chaperones that protect proteins during stress and help proteins fold, cross membranes, assemble and disassemble into complexes and become degraded . Hsp70s are involved in a large number of human diseases and the mechanisms of Hsp70 function are an important clinical consideration  . While these experiments provide insight into interactions of isolated components of the chaperone machinery with amyloid, it remains unclear how accurately they reflect how these and other factors influence dynamics of prion propagation in the highly complex environment of the cell .
Nanoparticle based in vivo diagnostic imaging is one part of the broad research field of nanomedicine that is currently the focus of numerous interdisciplinary research groups worldwide. Nanoscale diagnostic constructs are being developed for a range of imaging modalities such as positron emission tomography , single photon emission computed tomography , and magnetic resonance imaging , among others. , , , Although MRI can suffer from sensitivity issues, MRI based diagnostics have the benefit of both not relying on ionizing radiation and displaying larger contrast between different types of biological soft tissues, which is important in cancer diagnostics and imaging of the brain, muscle, and cardiovasculature.
Cannabis is one of the most widely used psychoactive substances in the United States . Perceived risk of use is associated with substance use; the recent debate surrounding medicalization and legalization of cannabis in the U.S. has the potential to impact perceived risk of use. Recent estimates are needed to assess temporal changes in, and identify correlates of, perceived risk of cannabis use .
Collagen induced arthritis  is an established mouse model of human rheumatoid arthritis . Immunization with heterologous collagen type II in susceptible mouse strains results in autoantibody production to murine collagen type II, followed by autoantibody binding to joint cartilage, activation of the complement cascade, and inflammation resulting in tissue destruction . Both MHC and non MHC genes are implicated in disease susceptibility .
Numerous proteins that are critical to cellular function are synthesized endoplasmic reticulum  ribosomes, then folded and further post translationally modified in the ER lumen. ER stress activates the transcription factors, X box binding protein  and activator of transcription 6 , which induce numerous ERSR proteins designed to restore efficient ER protein folding, which contributes to resisting the stress ,. Many ERSR genes are induced by ATF6 or XBP1, while others exhibit a requirement for only one of the two factors  .
Mallory Denk Bodies , which are an intracellular deposition of misfolded protein in ballooned hepatocytes, consist of abnormally phosphorylated, ubiquitylated, and cross linked keratins or non keratin K18 and 8, and p62 components . Balloon hepatocytes forming MDBs are progenitor preneoplasia cells . In the DDC fed mouse model where liver cells proliferate, MDBs form and later, after DDC withdrawal, HCCs develop .
A number of epidemiologic studies have associated pre  and post natal exposure toambient air pollution with adverse respiratory outcomes. Post natal exposures to airpollutants, including particulate matter , ozone , nitrogen dioxide, carbon monoxide , and sulfur dioxide , have beenassociated with increased infant mortality, even in developed countries such as the UnitedStates, with the strongest associations for post neonatal respiratory mortality . Although a number of studies report increased risks of respiratory symptoms inearly life in association with air pollution exposure,, relatively few studies havespecifically examined early life respiratory infection  in relation to traffic related emissions.
Our objective was to determine the probability threshold for recurrent symptoms at which elective cholecystectomy compared to observation in older patients with symptomatic cholelithiasis is the more effective and cost effective option . We built a decision model of elective cholecystectomy vs. observation in patients >65 presenting with initial episodes of symptomatic cholelithiasis that did not require initial hospitalization or cholecystectomy. Probabilities for subsequent hospitalization, emergency cholecystectomy, and perioperative complications were based on previously published probabilities from a 5% national sample of Medicare patients.
In the kidney, the proximal tubule reabsorbs 6070% of filtered NaCl and fluid. Therefore changes in proximal tubule reabsorption can have profound effects on renal and body fluid balance and may contribute to the development of hypertension. The normal kidney protects against acute increases in blood pressure by excreting NaCl rapidly.
The number of incarcerations in the US has dramatically increased in recent years . The proportion of female inmates accounts for less than 9% of the incarcerated population, but the number of female inmates in state and federal correctional facilities has grown faster  than the number of male incarcerations  between 1995 and 2007  . Typically, their socioeconomic difficulties exist before their incarceration .
Antibody mediated injury has reached epidemic proportions in kidney transplantation. Recent studies suggest that antibody mediated rejection  is the most important cause of allograft loss following kidney transplantation . In this new definition, C4d staining is not an absolute requirement for the diagnosis of ABMR.
Dental caries are the result of acidification of dental plaque, mainly by oral lactic acid bacteria, most notably Streptococcus mutans, but also other acid producing plaque bacteria. Other environmental stresses, such as oxidative or starvation stress, may act in conjunction with acidification in causing damage. Another common way for oral bacteria to protect themselves against acid damage is through the production of alkali .
The nuclear envelope, comprised of the inner and outer nuclear membranes , define the nuclear rim and separate the nucleus from the cytoplasm. B type lamins, subdivided into lamins B1 and B2, are products of individual genes . Because of their large size, progeny virions cannot exit through nuclear pores and therefore must cross the nuclear lamina to bud through the INM.
Clinical and epidemiological data has associated an inflammatory microenvironment with cancer development . Most tumors show evidence of infiltrating immune and inflammatory cells, and chronic inflammatory disorders are known to increase the overall risk of cancer development. The IL 6 family of cytokines, which includes IL 6, Oncostatin M  IL 11, leukemia inhibitory factor , cardiotrophin 1 , ciliary neurotrophic factor , and cardiotrophin like cytokine  are secreted by immune cells, stromal cells, and epithelial cells, and regulate diverse processes .
Hereditary deafness is phenotypically and genetically heterogeneous affecting nearly 300 million people worldwide. Genetically, it has been estimated that ~1% of all human genes may be implicated in the etiology of hereditary deafness., The major challenges and goals in the field have been to identify all the genes containing mutations leading to deafness and to decipher the functions of the encoded protein in auditory and vestibular pathways. In the last five years, the emergence of genome enrichment arrays followed by massively parallel sequencing  technologies has accelerated gene discovery for human disorders, including deafness.
The qualities of a self specific T lymphocyte that define its pathogenicity are incompletely understood. TCR affinity may have dual roles in defining a T cell's autoimmune potential. Increased affinity may promote central and peripheral tolerance .
Globally, the estimate of those with an active headache disorder is 46% of the adult population. Cervicogenic headache  is a type of headache causally associated with cervical myofascial tender spots or cervical spine dysfunction. The reported prevalence of CGH varies from 13.8% to 17.8% of the headache population in different epidemiological studies.
Great Danes  with cervical spondylomyelopathy  are most frequently affected by the osseous associated form, which is characterized by vertebral canal stenosis secondary to osseous proliferation of the vertebral arch, articular processes and/or pedicles . Magnetic resonance imaging  is the imaging modality of choice for dogs with suspected CSM  . The morphologic MRI features of GDs with osseous associated CSM have been described retrospectively .
Synthetic biology aims at engineering tunable gene circuits, with standardized components , whose properties then can be extensively studied by combining experiments and computational modeling. However, little attention has been paid to the question of dynamical mechanism. cannot transform one mechanism into another.
When viewing a stimulus with two or more distinct interpretations, observers experience perceptual switches between the two alternatives. Well known examples are binocular rivalry , ambiguous figures , and figure/ground illusions such as the face vase . For both binocular rivalry and ambiguous motion displays, the dynamics of the perceptual alternations were found to be stationary .
Improving the quality of care in nursing homes has been a major theme in health care for over 30 years. In this vein, a number of structural and process characteristics of nursing homes have been examined over the years in terms of their relationship with quality. Characteristics such as facility size, ownership, chain membership, facility resources and culture, medical treatments offered, specialized care settings, and percent private pay have all been related to outcomes.
More than two thirds of individuals with psychiatric disabilities  receiving mental health services want to work . Supported Employment  is an effective method to increase employment among individuals with psychiatric disabilities  with an employment rate approaching 60% . Thus, this population still faces major barriers to employment  .
Major depressive disorder  carries a significant risk of suicidal behavior . Studying suicide attempts is an important method to identify those at risk of future completion, since they are more common in the general population and strong risk factors for suicide . Depression severity , comorbid personality , anxiety , and alcohol use disorders  have all been associated with an elevated risk of suicide attempt.
Pathogenic HIV infection of humans and SIV infection of rhesus macaques  are characterized by progressive depletion of CD4+ T cells and development of a lethal state of immunodeficiency termed AIDS . In contrast, SIV infection of African nonhuman primate species that are natural hosts for the virus, such as the sooty mangabeys  and the African green monkeys , are typically nonpathogenic despite high virus replication . According to this model, CD4+ TCM are essential to maintain the overall CD4+ T cell homeostasis due to their in vivo longevity and high proliferative potential resulting in the ability to maintain their pool as well as the more differentiated pool of CD4+ effector memory  T cells .
Thymidylate synthases  catalyze the reductive methylation of 2′ deoxyuridine 5′ monophosphate  to form 2′ deoxythymidine 5′ monophosphate  in nearly all eukaryotes including humans. This reaction employs N5, N10 methylene 5,6,7,8 tetrahydrofolate  as both the methylene and the hydride donor , producing 7,8 dihydrofolate , as illustrated in . Thus, the genomes of thyA dependent organisms have always been found to contain folA as well, forming a TS DHFR coupled catalytic cycle that is essential for thymidine biosynthesis .
The p21 Ras family of monomeric GTPases function as molecular switches relaying signals from cell surface receptors to intracellular kinase cascades regulating cell proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis and senescence . The three ubiquitously expressed Ras isoforms: H Ras, K Ras 4B  and N Ras, share almost complete sequence homology between amino acids 1 165. However, tumour profiling, knock out mice, localisation and over expression studies have provided evidence for Ras isoform specific signalling  .
Nicotine is the primary addictive component of tobacco smoke . For example, nicotine upregulates the expression of immediate early genes such as c Fos, c Jun, Nurr77, and Egr1 . Through its interaction directly or indirectly with these genes, pathways, and neurotransmitter systems, nicotine is involved in the regulation of various physiological processes , as well as the morphology and function of different organelles  .
As members of the sodium and chloride dependent neurotransmitter transporter gene family, serotonin  transporters  carry out the uptake of 5 HT across plasma membranes in the central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, placenta, platelets, and pulmonary system. , Hydropathy analyses initially suggested that SERTs are integral membrane proteins with 12 α helices. ,, Mutagenesis of key residues has provided insight into the structure and function of SERT.
The deposition of β amyloid  in the form of diffuse , primitive , and classic  deposits is one of the pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease  and Down’s syndrome  . In AD and DS, Aβ deposits up to 150 μm in diameter can be observed in single sections of the cerebral cortex . A statistical mechanics approach has been adopted to model the growth of Aβ deposits in AD .
Initial investigations of cancer focused on the proximate causes of the disease ; however, more recent studies have addressed the ultimate causes behind the persistence of cancer . For example, the tumor suppression gene TP53 is not only effective at suppressing cancer, but also stem cells that replenish worn out tissues . Several behavioral studies have highlighted the specific importance of melanin patterns in sexual selection  and found that the same phenotype can play a role in both mate choice and male male competition.
Physical activity in children is an important determinant of health   . While studies have examined the association between physical activity and environmental factors and sociodemographic factors, few studies have reported on the role of specific physical characteristics such as eyesight that might influence physical activity . Myopia, or short sightedness, has been estimated to affect 8.4% of 412 year olds in Australia and 9.2% of 517 year olds in the U.S.A.  Children from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children  were asked to wear a uniaxial accelerometer for seven days.
For decades, coronary artery bypass graft surgery  has been the treatment of choice for symptomatic patients with medically refractory multi vessel coronary artery disease  . Recently, drug eluting stents were shown to reduce the incidence of in stent restenosis and target lesion revascularization . The combined primary endpoint was death, stroke, myocardial infarction or repeat revascularization at 12 months.
Kv2.1 channels are the principal component of sustained outward K+ currents  in hippocampus and cortex and are found in large, highly phosphorylated clusters on the soma and proximal dendrites of pyramidal neurons . It has been proposed that the cellular location of Kv2.1 channels allows for control of somatic sub threshold excitatory responses, and ultimately, regulation of action potential initiation . However, knock down of Kv2.1 channels increases excitability of CA1 pyramidal neurons only during high frequency, but not low frequency stimulation , suggesting that these channels function differently than typical delayed rectifier channels  .
The hunting spider Cupiennius salei Keys is a nocturnal predator that has been in focus of interest for a long time because of its excellent mechano sensory systems. showed that a visual stimulus alone can elicit attack behaviour. The rhabdomeres of the receptor cells of the AM eyes are orientated towards the light.
During development, morphogenetic movements are induced and controlled by a variety of molecules such as growth factors or hormones and their receptors. These hormones regulate gene expression patterns required for development. Following changes in gene expression, cells change shape and move by processes that require remodeling of the extracellular matrix  and alterations in the interactions of cell surface adhesion molecules with their intracellular and extracellular ligands.
Recently, a new concept is emerging that activation of the inflammasomes, in particular, the Nlrp3  inflammasome, plays a critical role in the development of vascular diseases . It has been known that the Nlrp3 inflammasome usually consists of three main components including Nlrp3 that functions as pattern recognition receptor, the adaptor protein, ASC  and inactive pro caspase 1 protein . Recently, Nlrp3 inflammasome activation has also been reported to produce the regulatory or pathogenic actions in cells or tissues beyond the classical inflammatory response.
The peritrichs are classified into two assemblages : the free living Sessilida and the parasitic Mobilida with their characteristic adhesive disk. The Sessilida, which includes the species described here, comprises about 105  to 140  genera, showing the great diversity of the group. Although a comprehensive recent review is not available, these genera comprise at least 800 described species.
Nitric oxide , a ubiquitous cellular signaling molecule, is one of the most studied small molecules in biology due to its involvement in numerous biological processes such as vasodilation, neurotransmission and immune response . There is still much that is unknown about how NO production by nitric oxide synthase  is tightly regulated . There are three mammalian NOS isoforms: endothelial NOS , neuronal NOS , and inducible NOS .
In the United States, the prevalence of adolescents who are obese has more than tripled over the past thirty years, increasing from 5% in 1976 to over 18% in 2008 . With the high prevalence of adolescent obesity, identification of physiological and psychological factors associated with obesity has become a national priority . Obese individuals may exhibit disordered eating behaviors or patterns, including binge eating.
Microparticles  are membrane encapsulated vesicles of less than 1 μm diameter shed by all types of cells, including platelets, red blood cells , leukocytes, epithelial cells of various tissue origins, as well as tumor cells . MPs are released during cell activation, apoptosis, cell senescence, cell lysis and oxidative stress. Published recommendations for the collection and handling of plasma samples for proteomic analysis differ in type of anticoagulant, types of collection tubes, holding temperature of whole blood , use of protease inhibitors .
Stroke is the 4th leading cause of death in the United States and the leading cause of long term disability. Over 7 million Americans have had a stroke . The American Heart Association predicts that by 2030, the direct cost of caring for stroke patients will triple from $61.55 billion to $183.13 billion, due in large part to increasing life expectancy, declining stroke related mortality and aging U.S. population.
c Myc is a transcription factor implicated in many cellular processes such as proliferation, and apoptosis  and is over expressed in most cancers . The c Myc protein belongs to the basic helix loop helix leucine zipper protein family , and forms a dimer with the ubiquitously expressed protein Max. The dimer binds to the specific CACTG motif designated as E  boxes and thereby regulates transcription of target genes both positively and negatively .
Atrial fibrillation  is the most common sustained dysrhythmia, affecting over 2 million people in the United States. Preventing AF is a priority given the high lifetime risk for developing the condition, the projected increase in population burden, and the substantial morbidity and mortality associated with the disease. Identification and characterization of intermediate phenotypes for AF may identify high risk individuals prior to disease onset.
Survival after out of hospital cardiac arrest  varies widely betweencommunities. These differences reflectdifferences in the distribution of patient risk factors and severity of disease; thestructure and function of emergency medical services ; and the method of measuring theprocess and outcome of care. Experts developed and disseminated the Utstein template tostandardize methods of measuring care for patients with OHCA to improve the comparabilitywithin and between communities of reports of risk factors, quality of care and outcomesafter OHCA.
Pulmonary arterial hypertension  involves abnormal proliferation of pulmonary vascular cells, resulting in pulmonary arterial remodeling and obliteration of the pulmonary vascular lumen. Ultimate clinical outcomes include increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right ventricular  failure. However, despite these advancements, there is a clear need for better understanding of the mechanisms of the disease process, given the persistently high mortality rates in this patient population.
Electrical injuries represent a small proportion of the total burn injuries that occur in North America , . The mechanisms of thermal and electrical injury are inherently different. Although soft tissue injury at the contact points may be detected on examination, deep tissue injury from electrical current may not be visible on initial clinical presentation .
Sleep disorders are reported in Parkinson’s disease, Dementia with Lewy Bodies and Alzheimer’ Disease . Whilst the pathophysiology of sleep disorders in these diseases remains unclear, it has been linked with reduced hypocretin levels in other sleep disorders such as narcolepsy . Hypocretins 1 and 2,  are hypothalamic neuropeptides, initially identified and investigated as regulators of food intake but which have more recently been shown to stimulate wakefulness  .
Over the last two decades, neuroimaging experiments have substantially increased our knowledge of how the brain processes pain, both in health and disease . The vast majority of the studies published so far, however, predominantly focuses on brain activations, and tends to neglect brain deactivations . Nonetheless, some studies indicate that an investigation of deactivations might yield a fuller understanding of central pain processing.
Differences in both drinking patterns and alcohol related outcomes have been found in US comparisons of Hispanic, Non Hispanic white and Non Hispanic black race/ethnicity groups. Hispanic and black groups have been found to have more extreme drinking patterns relative to whites with higher levels of abstention, a higher proportion of heavy drinking among drinkers and less reduction of heavy drinking with age . African American male drinkers have been found to be more likely to consume spirits and malt liquor beer and to have particularly large drinks and high daily intake from these beverage types in a community sample .
Breast cancer incidence and mortality varies widely among women of different population groups in the U.S. African American women have lower age adjusted incidence of breast cancer compared with European Americans . However, breast cancer incidence is higher in African Americans who are 35 years of age or younger . The expression of steroid hormone receptors  in breast cancer tumors also varies substantially by population.
Anti N methyl D aspartate receptor  encephalitis is an immune mediated disorder that associates with IgG antibodies against the GluN1 subunit of the NMDAR. In contrast, brain immunohistochemistry which produces a highly characteristic pattern of reactivity, and may reveal additional antibodies, combined with CBA with fixed cells expressing GluN1/2 which confirms the identity of the antigen, were kept as a set of techniques that since 2007 we have routinely used in serum or CSF, of all patients regardless of sex, age, or syndrome . Over the years we have studied anecdotal patients who had a clinical picture characteristic of anti NMDAR encephalitis but serum testing was negative in other laboratories.
Circadian  rhythms are driven by cell autonomous clocks that are generally composed of interconnected transcriptional and translational feedback loops . Studies using Drosophila have made seminal contributions to our understanding of clock mechanisms in general and those of animals in particular . dPER and TIM interact in the cytoplasm, an event that promotes their nuclear entry , where it is thought that the binding of dPER to dCLK is a crucial step in blocking the transcriptional activity of the dCLK CYC complex .
Microarray probes are designed to match the sequences of the target genes in the selected reference genome. However, due to individual and population variation, some probes may not exactly match the sequence of the RNA applied to the arrays. The polymorphisms that are most likely encountered in microarray experiments are single nucleotide polymorphisms  because they are much more abundant than any other type of polymorphisms in most species including human and mouse .
It is generally accepted that GnRH is secreted in pulses from the hypothalamus . The cellular basis for this pulse activity is not completely understood. These cultures consisted only of GnRH expressing cells and were found to release GnRH in a rhythmic fashion .
The tumor necrosis factor  receptorassociated factor  family of adaptor proteins promotes the activation of several transcription factors to induce immune and inflammatory responses, including nuclear factor kB , activator protein 1 , and interferon  regulatory factors 3 and 7 , which are especially important for innate immune antiviral function . The molecular specificities that determine the individual TRAF protein functions, including the role of TRAF3 in stimulating IFN secretion, however, still remain incompletely defined . The TRAF interacting motif  of Cardif has been mapped to three regions, including the TRAF2 binding motif  143PVQDT147, TRAF6 binding motif 1  153PVENSE159, and TRAF6 binding motif 2  431PEENEY437 .
Cardiogenic shock  complicates 58% of all cases of acute myocardial infarction  and is a common cause of death in patients hospitalized with MI An estimated 120,000140,000 patients in North America and Europe develop CS annually. Early revascularization  has a large, favorable impact on one year survival. However, not all patients receive early revascularization and there remains wide variability in mortality rates from CS with and without early revascularization and use of other support measures, from less than 30 to over 80%., Previous studies have identified patient, MI and treatment determinants of outcome,, Published risk models have primarily examined populations undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention  or participating in fibrinolytic trials.,, A robust risk model applicable to a broader group of shock patients would be useful not only for discussion of benefits and risks of therapeutic options with patients and families, but also for health care policies on resource utilization and in risk adjustment for outcome reporting from quality improvement programs.
Sleep characteristics that represent insufficient or poor quality sleep are associated with the development of coronary heart disease  and stroke in population studies. A number of pathophysiologic processes that are correlated with sleep and CHD could account for the relationship including inflammation, autonomic dysfunction,, endothelial dysfunction and insulin resistance. However, the contribution of the coagulation system is less well studied despite its plausibility as an alternative pathway .
As a pivotal part of the innate immunity, complement exists at high concentration in serum as well as in many other body fluids to fight against infections . At the same time, the terminal pathway of complement activation assembles membrane attack complexes , which lyses target cells by forming osmotic channels on cell surfaces . Since complement activation products cannot distinguish self cells from invading pathogens, self cells depend on surface complement regulators to protect them from autologous complement mediated injury.
A decade of studies using high throughput genomics and proteomics data revealed that cancer cells differ from normal cells in both RNA and protein contents. Not surprisingly, a substantial number of tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes are in fact transcription factors . In fact, a good portion of aberrant protein expression in tumors has its origin at the post transcriptional level.
Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer and second leading cause of cancer death among African American women . Healthcare disparities have been documented across the spectrum of breast cancer detection and treatment: African American women are less likely to be diagnosed with early stage disease, less likely to receive breast sparing treatment, less likely to receive adjuvant treatment, and more likely to die compared to White women .
